p: Traditional medicine (TM), as defined by the World Health Organization (WHO), is the sum total of the knowledge, skills and practices based on the theories, beliefs and experiences indigenous to different cultures, whether explicable or not, used in the maintenance of health as well as in the prevention, diagnosis, improvement or treatment of physical and mental illness (WHO 2002a, 2002b). Some TM systems are supported by huge volumes of literature and records of the theoretical concepts and practical skills; others pass down from generation to generation through verbal teaching. To date, in some parts of the world, the majority of the population continue to rely on their own TM to meet their primary health care needs. When adopted outside of its traditional culture, TM is often referred as complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) (Che etÂ al. 2017).
